meanings.def: a spacecraft in the shape of a tube that is driven by a stream of gases let out behind it when fuel is burned inside
examples: The idea took off like a rocket (= it immediately became popular).

meanings.def: a missile (= a weapon that travels through the air) that carries a bomb and is driven by a stream of burning gases
examples: A rocket smashed into the side of the building.

meanings.def: a firework that goes high into the air and then explodes with coloured lights
a plant with long green leaves that have a strong taste and are eaten raw in salads
to speak angrily to somebody because they have done something wrong; to be spoken to angrily for this reason

idioms.idiom: to give somebody a rocket | to get a rocket
idioms.def: to speak angrily to somebody because they have done something wrong; to be spoken to angrily for this reason

meanings.def: to increase very quickly and suddenly
examples: The total has rocketed from 376 to 532.
They were forced to move out because of the rocketing crime rate.
The car rocketed out of a side street.

meanings.def: to achieve or to make somebody/something achieve a successful position very quickly
examples: rocket (somebody/something) to something The band rocketed to stardom with their first single.

meanings.def: to attack a place with rockets

the name of an early steam engine (= vehicle that pulls a train) designed in the 1820s by Robert Stephenson. It was the first engine to be used regularly on the Liverpool and Manchester Railway, and the original version of it is now in the Science Museum, London.
